Protests show rising green concerns PUBLISHED : Wednesday , 04 July , 2012 , 12:00am Mass protests this week over the planned construction of a molybdenum-copper alloy plant in Shifang , Sichuan province show that environmental concerns are becoming a leading cause of social unrest .
Authorities yesterday said they would scrap the 10.4 billion yuan ( HK $ 12.7 billion ) project , the subject of demonstrations by tens of thousands of Shifang residents .

' Once the damage is done , it is long-lasting and not remediable . ' The massive three-day protest this week was the latest in a series of grass-roots demonstrations over polluting projects , as mainlanders have gained awareness in recent years of environmental and health concerns associated with pollution .
Last summer , tens of thousands of people in the northeastern city of Dalian , Liaoning , marched to demand the relocation of a chemical plant .
And in June 2007 , over 20,000 people rallied in Xiamen , a coastal city in Fujian province , to protest against plans to built a paraxylene chemical plant in the city .
Following the Xiamen incident , the ' not in my backyard ' mentality sparked similar protests in several mainland cities , including Dalian , Guangzhou and Shantou .
Analysts say the mainland public has taken to such protests because they lack adequate channels to express their concerns about environmental risks posed by massive industrial projects .

Ma Jun , director of the Institute of Public and Environmental Affairs in Beijing , said the Shifang protests came as a last resort for local residents to make their voices heard , as ' all other channels for public participation were ineffective ' .

Demonstrators have filed for a permit to hold a rally on Saturday in Yuen Long , the district on the outskirts of Hong Kong where dozens of masked men chased and beat commuters and protesters with wooden poles and metal rods , leaving at least 45 people in hospital .

Footage of the attack , which included a pregnant woman being hit , protesters being punched and kneed , and commuters screaming and crying while trying to shield themselves , emerged on Sunday night , fuelling further political unrest as demonstrators , opposition lawmakers and others demanded answers from authorities for failing to stop the violence .

Max Chung , who delivered the application for a letter of no objection from the police , that is required to hold a rally , said : “ We want to show to the public and international community that Hong Kongers , we will never surrender in front of terrorism … To show our solidarity and say no to terrorism , we have to stand up. ” Chung said : “ Yuen Long was under terrorist attack and we have no choice but to take it back. ” The protests , principally over a controversial bill that would allow suspects to be extradited from Hong Kong to mainland China , have taken on new demands , including an investigation into police use of rubber bullets , teargas and physical violence against protesters .
Protesters are angry at the police ’ s slow response to the attack in Yuen Long and their pursuit of the case .
The violence in Yuen Long has heightened tensions and fears of further attacks .
On Tuesday evening , unverified footage showed men in white gathering in Tuen Mun , another city near Yuen Long in the New Territories .

Hong Kong ’ s leader , Carrie Lam , said the “ shocking violence ” in Yuen Long would be investigated , but devoted most of her comments to criticising protesters , who surrounded Beijing ’ s liaison office in Hong Kong and defaced the national emblem of the People ’ s Republic of China on Sunday .

US Committed to Seeking Justice on Behalf of All 26/11 Victims 05th August 2015 12:04 PM NEW YORK : The US is committed to pursuing justice on behalf of the victims of the 2008 Mumbai attack no matter how " arduous " the task is , a top Indian-origin American diplomat has said .

" We have certainly reiterated our support and our commitment to India 's efforts to seek justice on behalf of the victims " of the 26/11 attack , Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs Nisha Desai Biswal told PTI when asked about the delay in bringing to justice the perpetrators of the 2008 terror attacks .

Biswal , who had travelled to the city from Washington to speak at the Indian Consulate General 's Media-India Lecture Series yesterday , said not only were there a large number of Indian victims in the attack but there were Americans also who lost their lives .

Given that nearly seven years have passed since the horrendous terror attacks that claimed over 160 lives and injured many others , Biswal said bringing justice for the victims in terror attacks may appear to be an arduous andlong-drawn process .
Biswal underlined that the US on its part had offered rewards for information leading to the arrest and prosecution of individuals associated with the Mumbai attack .
Referring to the terror attack in Punjab 's Gurdaspur district on July 27 , Biswal said the US has strongly condemned and expressed its concern over the attack .
She said the US has expressed its cooperation ith Indian authorities on on any specific aspects of the incident .

On media reports that the night vision device used by three terrorists in the Gurdaspur attack had US markings , Biswal said the US is in conversation with Indian authorities to try to ascertain and trace the origins of the equipment found .

" We will continue to work very closely with the Indian government on those issues , " she said , adding that it is an ongoing process and the US is working with Indian authorities to address issues of concern emanating from the incident .

Thousands of demonstrators marched in Hong Kong on Saturday , facing the threat of arrest and increasingly severe warnings from Beijing .

Protesters clad head to toe in black , carrying umbrellas and orange helmets , deviated from the route approved by police and took over a major road of the normally busy shopping district of Mongkok .
One group held a black banner with the words : “ The police have overstepped ” , while others chanted for the release of protesters who have been arrested over the last two months of demonstrations .
Protesters distributed protective gear such as face masks , in the event of clashes with police , who have used teargas on demonstrators .
The previously banned march was sanctioned by the police at the last minute and is one of several protests this weekend in Hong Kong .
As the city enters its ninth consecutive week of protests , the movement shows few signs of abating , as public anger at the government spreads to more parts of Hong Kong society .
Thousands of civil servants , medical workers and staff from the city ’ s finance sector rallied on Thursday and Friday , while further protests were planned through the weekend .

The protests , which began over a proposal to allow extradition to China , pose the most serious challenge to China ’ s authority over the city since 1997 , when it was returned from British to Chinese control .
In recent days , Beijing has ramped up its condemnation of the protests , which it describes as “ riots ” , and has accused the US and other western powers of instigating the unrest to hurt China .

On Thursday , Chen Daoxiang , the head of the Chinese army garrison in Hong Kong , said the military was “ determined to protect [ the ] national sovereignty ” of Hong Kong and would help put down the “ intolerable ” unrest if requested .
Hong Kong police on Thursday also charged 44 people linked to the protests with “ rioting ” , a crime that carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison .
On online forums there were claims that police decided to allow the previously banned protest in Mongkok in order to surround demonstrators and arrest them en masse .

Tens of thousands of pro-democracy protesters have marched across Hong Kong to mark the 20th anniversary of its return to Chinese control with a high-profile show of dissent .

China ’ s president Xi Jinping , who had been in the former British colony on a three-day tour , flew out of Hong Kong just hours before the annual protest kicked off in Victoria Park on Saturday afternoon .

“ We know he has gone back to Beijing but we still want to show that they can not ignore our voice , ” said Howard Cheng , 28 , one of the leaders of the group that organises the rally , the Civil Human Rights Front ( CHRF ) .

“ We are here to fight for democracy and universal suffrage. ” Organisers said more than 60,000 people joined the 3km march , which has been held nearly every year since Hong Kong returned to China in 1997 .
Saturday ’ s rally , which will be followed by a massive pro-Beijing firework display celebrating the anniversary , kicked off at about 3.30pm local time .

A column of protestors surged westwards from the park towards Hong Kong ’ s financial centre , carrying flags , banners and yellow umbrellas – the symbol of 2014 ’ s mass protests – stamped with the words : “ Power to the people ” .

Many demonstrators carried messages of dissent on black and white T-shirts emblazoned with slogans such as : “ Never back down ” , “ fight for Hong Kong , ” and , more poetically , “ being born in uncertain times carries certain responsibilities ” .
We are here to tell the world that , ” Nathan Law , a local pro-democracy legislator who was among those leading the rally , told the Guardian .
Eddie Chu , a 39-year-old environmentalist and pro-democracy politician , said the rally was “ the most important chance to show the power of the people ” .
This is what we need. ” Jason Leung a 16-year-old protestor , was marching with a poster carrying a rather different message .
“ I think it is very selfish , ” explained the teenager , who was at his first rally and said he had come because he wanted to experience first-hand Hong Kong ’ s vibrant democracy movement .
Hong Kong is not China. ” Xi Jinping was hundreds of kilometres away by the time Saturday ’ s protest began but he left demonstrators a clear message before his departure .

He said in an address before the protests began that Hong Kong must not be used as a launchpad to challenge Beijing ’ s authority and any questioning of China ’ s sovereignty in the territory “ crosses a red line ” .
Both of these issues remain deeply unpopular among city residents and previous government attempts to enact security legislation and national education sparked mass protests .

“ It is absolutely impermissible. ” Little more than an hour before Xi ’ s speech , democracy protesters were attacked by pro-China demonstrators and hauled away by police as they attempted to march on the daily flag-raising ceremony .

Thousands of heavily armed troops have paraded through cities in China ’ s troubled far west with officials there vowing a “ thunderous ” anti-terror crackdown after an apparent upsurge in deadly ethnic violence .

The parades come after two separate eruptions of bloodletting claimed more than a dozen lives in Xinjiang , a sprawling border region which has been blighted by repeated outbreaks of ethnic violence and terrorist attacks .
Last Tuesday three machete-wielding attackers were reported to have been gunned down by police after they killed five civilians in Hotan ’ s Pishan county .
On 28 December four assailants were reportedly shot dead after using home-made explosives to launch a deadly assault on a government compound in Karakax county .

China says Islamic extremists and separatists are behind such attacks although human rights activists suspect much of the violence is driven by resentment at Communist party rule among the region ’ s predominantly Muslim ethnic Uighur population .

“ Chen has gone in the opposite direction with these military parades which are quite remarkable really … We saw similar-type events after the 2009 riots but here we are talking about in response to what was really a small knife attack in Hotan .

So it is out of proportion , I would say , to the level of violence that we have seen in Xinjiang this year. ” China ’ s leaders declared a “ people ’ s war on terror ” in 2014 after a series of attacks that took place or were linked to Xinjiang .
Those incidents included a street bombing in Urumqi , a knife attack on civilians at a train station in Kunming , and a car-bomb attack in Beijing ’ s Tiananmen Square .
However , until the recent killings a period of relative calm appeared to have descended on the region .

The stone pelting resulted in injuries to about 12 security personnel , he said .
No student suffered injuries in the incident , Ladda said .

The fresh clash came a day after over 22 people , including five media men and 11 security personnel with an officer among them , were injured last night when students agitating over creation of a separate Telangana hurled stones at them on the Osmania University campus prompting them to use force to quell the mob .

Following this , the police appealed to the agitators to withdraw the strike .
The workers lifted the road blockade , but continued with their agitation near the factory premises .

OPINION India ’ s Pakistan problem is Pakistan ’ s problem too December 03 , 2008 00:00 IST Siddharth Varadarajan If politics and emotion do not dictate India ’ s response , the terrorist strikes in Mumbai could be a catalyst for ending the Pakistani military ’ s fatal patronage of jihadi groups .

In the charged atmosphere generated by the dangerous currents of domestic politics and media-induced panic , Prime Minister Manmohan Singh is finding himself under tremendous pressure to respond decisively to initial evidence that ‘ elements in Pakistan ’ were responsible for last week ’ s terrorist outrage in Mumbai .

External Affairs Minister Pranab Mukherjee got off to a sober and dignified start last week when he told his Pakistani counterpart that the elements responsible for the carnage did not want a “ leap forward ” in relations between India and Pakistan and were hence acting against Islamabad ’ s interests as well .

And on Monday , India issued a demarche to Pakistan in which it said it expected “ strong action ” against those responsible for the attacks , “ whosoever they may be . ” But with TV channels declaring “ enough is enough ” and calling for the start of a “ real war ” on terror , the government finds itself increasingly on the back foot .
Too early It is too early to say how these demands for an immediate and decisive response to what happened in Mumbai will affect relations with Pakistan .

One would have thought the futility of offensive troop deployments and the suspension or downgrading of normal transport and diplomatic relations — methods the BJP-led Vajpayee government unsuccessfully tried after the terrorist attack on Parliament in December 2001 — would be apparent by now .

“ But as the political and media pressure mounts , it becomes harder for us to exercise those options . ” The executioners of the terrorist attack on Pakistan , of course , would like nothing better than for India to get trapped into an aggressive , and preferably , military response .

Thanks to the providential arrest of a terrorist in Mumbai and his subsequent interrogation , the police are asserting with a considerable degree of confidence that the LeT planned and orchestrated the attacks that took the lives of more than 180 people .

Whether the terrorists who attacked Mumbai belong to a group that has attacked Pakistani targets or had handlers with links to elements within the Pakistani military establishment , there is enough evidence to suggest that it is impossible for GHQ in Rawalpindi to firewall the two .
The brutal murder of Daniel Pearl showed the ease with which a ‘ Kashmir-inspired ’ terrorist like Omar Saeed Sheikh could make the al - Qaeda ’ s agenda his own .
And the deliberate targeting of U.S. and British citizens and Jews in the Mumbai attacks should be a further reminder to Washington of the danger of allowing groups like LeT any breathing space .

NIA 's chargesheet leaves crime branch red-faced 26th December 2011 02:32 PM NEW DELHI : Mumbai Police 's elite Crime Branch 's probe into the role of Fahim Ansari and Sabbauddin Ahmed in the conspiracy behind 26/11 finds no mention in the exhaustive charge sheet filed by NIA regarding the role of Pakistani-American LeT terrorist David Headley in the Mumbai attack .

The 60 - page charge sheet , filed by National Investigation Agency(NIA) on Saturday before a special court in New Delhi , details reconnaissance activities carried out by 50 - year-old Headley of the targets attacked by Lashker-e-Taiba(LeT) terrorists on November 26 , 2008 that left 166 people dead .

Mumbai Crime Branch had accused Ansari and Sabbauddin of providing details of the targets attacked by the LeT during 60 hour gun battle and had to face embarrassment twice when the trial court and the Bombay High Court acquitted the two saying there was no evidence against the two .

Former Commissioner of Mumbai Police Hasan Gafoor and the then in-charge of the Crime Branch , Rakesh Maria , who is at present head of Anti Terror Squad , had repeatedly claimed that Ansari and Ahmed had carried out reconnaissance of various targets attacked by Lashkar terrorists on November 26 , 2008 .

In its revision petition , the Crime Branch had again claimed that Ansari and Ahmed had played a role in providing details to to the Pakistan-based terror outfit about the targets attacked by terrorists on November 26 .

The investigation agency has gone into the role of Headley and eight others including founder of Lashker Hafiz Saeed , mastermind of 26/11 Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi and two serving Pakistani Army officials .

The statement of Headley , who was recruited by Lashker , to the US authorities and NIA before a magistrate , which forms as one of the annexures of the charge sheet , talks about his role in carrying out the survey of the locations attacked by the terrorists on 26/11 .

The division bench of Bombay High Court comprising justices Ranjana Desai and R V More while dismissing the plea of state government earlier this year had said " we are of the view that the view taken by learned Sessions Judge so far as involvement of the duo in this case is concerned , cannot be called unreasonable , palpably false , manifestly erroneous and demonstratively unsustainable which merits our interference . " The High court concurred with the view taken by Sessions Judge that the map recovered from killed terrorist pocket should have some wrinkles on it and blood spots as the LeT terrorist was badly injured in the gun-fight .
The NIA has given details about how every target attacked by LeT terrorists was scouted by Headley , who is at present in a Chicago jail . .

Timeline of major Maoist attacks 17th May 2010 07:32 PM NEW DELHI : The deadly Maoist guerrilla attack on a civilian bus in Chhattisgarh 's Dantewada district Monday evening comes just over a month after the Left rebels ' audacious April 6 attack on security forces in the same area , killing 76 personnel .

Some of the major Maoist guerrilla attacks in past : April 6 , 2010 : 76 security personnel , of whom 75 belonged to the Central Reserve Police Force ( CRPF ) , slaughtered by Maoists in the Chintalnar forested hamlet of Dantewada district .
April 4 , 2010 : Maoists detonate powerful landmine and blow up police bus in Koraput district , Orissa , killing around 10 Special Operations Group personnel and injuring 16 .
March 23 , 2010 : Maoists blast a railway track in Bihar 's Gaya district , causing derailment of the Bhubaneswar-New Delhi Rajdhani Express .
On the same day , a landmine attack in Orissa leaves an empty freight train derailed and hitting railway services on the Howrah-Mumbai route .
Feb 15 , 2010 : Around 100 Maoists storm a police camp in Silda , West Bengal , killing 24 policemen and looting arms .
Oct 8 , 2009 : 17 policemen were killed in an ambush by Maoists at Laheri police station in Gadchiroli district of Maharashtra .
July 27 , 2009 : Six CRPF men killed in a landmine blast at Dantewada district in Chhattisgarh .
July 12 , 2009 : Three separate attacks in Rajnandgaon district of Chhattisgarh claim the lives of 30 security personnel .
June 23 , 2009 : A group of motorcycle-borne armed Maoists open fire on Lakhisarai district court premises in Bihar to free four of their men .
June 10 , 2009 : Nine security personnel , including CRPF troopers , ambushed by Maoists during a routine patrol in Saranda jungles in Jharkhand .
May 22 , 2009 : Maoists kill 16 policemen in the jungles of Gadchiroli district in Maharashtra .
April 13 , 2009 : Around 10 policemen are killed in eastern Orissa 's Koraput district when Maoists attack a state-run bauxite mine .

DOMESTIC VIOLENCE - Indian Express Sun Aug 03 2008 , 12:04 hrs It has been a disturbing six months for India 's internal security : first the Naxal attacks in Orissa and the bomb blasts in Bangalore and Ahmedabad .
civilians and security forces killed in Naxals attacks in 2008 .
July 25 : Terror struck the IT capital of Bangalore as at least nine low intensity serial blasts rocked the city , leaving two dead and several injured .

The attacks were the first in the city after the Akshardham terror strike of 2002 .
May 13 : Eight serial bomb blasts at Johari Bazaar , Hanuman temple , Hawa Mahal , Badi Chaupad , Tripolia Bazaar and Chandpole in Jaipur .

June 29 : 35 security force personnel belonging to the Greyhounds from Andhra Pradesh were killed in a Naxal attack on a 68 - member Andhra Pradesh-Orissa police party in the Chitrakonda reservoir of Malkangiri district , close to the Andhra Pradesh border .

Polling peaceful barring one death , skirmishes 24th April 2009 07:25 AM HYDERABAD : Amid apprehensions of large-scale violence , particularly in the Rayalaseema region , the second phase of polling went off peacefully in the State , except for the death of a polling agent in Prakasam district while activists of rival political parties clashed at several places .
In all , 30 incidents were reported from various districts and 31 Electronic Voting Machines ( EVMs ) were damaged .
According to police , a polling agent , Ch Ramesh , succumbed to injuries after he was attacked by the workers of a rival party in Pariapalem village of Addanki mandal in Prakasam district .
In Kadapa district , EVMs were damaged at 19 polling stations at Rayachoti , Pulivendula , Kamalapuram , Rajampet , Mydukuru and Budvel .
In Pulivendula and Kamalapuram alone , EVMs were damaged at seven polling stations each .
Miscreants either poured water on the machines or damaged them with sticks .
In Anantapur district , EVMs were damaged at eight polling stations while in Prakasam , the machines were damaged at six polling stations .
EVMs were damaged at two polling stations each in Guntur and West Godavari districts , and one polling station each in Chittoor , East Godavari and Krishna districts .

In Chapadu mandal of Kadapa , the gunman of Janata Dal ( S ) candidate opened several rounds of fire in the air while in Mydukuru in the same district , Congress and TDP workers clashed at Nagasanipally , forcing the police to open 26 rounds in the air to disperse the mobs .
Some members of the groups even hurled crude bombs but none was injured .
There were complaints about polling agents being kidnapped in Kadapa , Anantapur and Kurnool districts which are being verified .
At Pitchaturu village in Satyaveedu constituency of Chittoor district , a polling officer was manhandled by the polling agents and the police is verifying the case .
Senior police officials , while referring to it as a major achievement , said there were only 30 incidents when compared to the 350 incidents during the 2004 elections .
Moreover , there was no loss of life or injuries to any person resulting out of use of fire arms or explosives by the warring groups , police officials said .
In all , 58 persons were arrested for indulging in violence .

In the 1980s , there was a series of student protests in China , culminating in the Tiananmen demonstrations of 1989 , when not just students but city dwellers all across the country joined the rallies .
Back then , the demonstrations were largely motivated by concern for the fate of the nation and a desire to see democratic freedoms put in place .
Concerned that this new policy would reduce their children ’ s chances of getting into university , they marched in the streets to protest .

Something similar happened a few years ago in Shanghai , when retirees took to the streets , worried that if welfare funds were allocated to poor areas , their own retirement benefits would be slashed .
In recent years , for instance , many retired military veterans have gathered together across the country in protests against the stingy benefits and pensions they receive from the state .
Other mass incidents , such as the widespread demonstrations by truck drivers in June , have been sparked by the fierce economic competition that now characterises life in China .

Anti-government protesters in Hong Kong took over key roads early on Monday amid rising tensions ahead of what expected to be a huge pro-democracy rally on the anniversary of the city ’ s handover to China .
The semi-autonomous city has been shaken by historic demonstrations in the past month , when protesters have demanded the withdrawal of a bill that would allow extraditions to the Chinese mainland .

While an official ceremony took place at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre to mark the 22nd anniversary of the return of sovereignty from Britain to China , tensions spiked once more in the financial hub after hundreds of mainly young , masked protesters mostly in black wearing hard hats and goggles seized three key thoroughfares , some deploying metal and plastic barriers to block the way .
Hundreds of protesters shouted “ retract the evil law ” in the torrential rain at one point .
On Lung Wo Road , some protesters dug up bricks and built make-shift barricades from roadside metal railings .
The ongoing rallies are the latest manifestation of growing fears that China is stamping down on the city ’ s freedoms and culture with the help of the finance hub ’ s pro-Beijing leaders .
There have been large-scale protests in Hong Kong in recent years , including a two-month occupation in 2014 – but have failed to win any concessions from Beijing .

This year ’ s rally comes against the backdrop of unprecedented anti-government protests over the past three weeks that have drawn millions and anger over police using tear gas and rubber bullets to clear crowds .

Millions have taken to the streets to protest against the proposed law allowing for the extradition of individuals for trial in mainland China , where the opaque court system is controlled by the Communist party .

The protests throughout June have been largely peaceful , but on 12 June , the scene turned violent when police used rubber bullets , teargas , pepper spray and batons to disperse crowds and some protesters threw objects back at the police .

Protesters have also surrounded the police headquarters twice in past weeks in noisy and emotionally charged protests in which young people spray-painted obscenities on its front wall and barricaded its entrances .

While the spark for the current wave of protests was an attempt by chief executive Carrie Lam to pass the Beijing-backed extradition law , the demonstrations have morphed into a wider movement against Lam ’ s administration and Beijing .

Lam – who has kept out of the public eye since her climbdown and has record low approval ratings – struck a conciliatory note Monday at the ceremony marking the handover , saying a series of protests that have rocked her city have taught her that she needs to listen better to the youth and people in general .

Eddy Chu Hoi-dick , a pro-democracy lawmaker , said while he worries about violence breaking out , he believes the young protesters in the leaderless protests have “ consensus about when they should back down ” and avoid arrest .
On Sunday , thousands of pro-government protesters rallied outside the government headquarters in support of the city ’ s police .
Many waved Chinese flags and hurled insults at anti-government demonstrators camped nearby , highlighting the deep ideological fissures now dividing the finance hub .

Within hours of the Chinese government making it clear that the people of Hong Kong will not have a free choice when they vote to elect the territory ’ s next chief executive , Hong Kong police had made their first arrests of demonstrators protesting against that decision .

This led to violent protests across the city the next day , with a group of students even storming into the university campus and demanding the dismissal of the teacher who had set the question paper .

A peaceful march in the town of Yuen Long to condemn an attack by suspected gang members on commuters turned violent as Hong Kong riot police fired teargas and rubber bullets on the crowd and used batons to beat protesters .
Organisers said almost 300,000 protesters and residents on Saturday afternoon defied a police ban to descend on the town in Hong Kong ’ s western New Territories .
They marched to the mass transit station where masked men in white T-shirts had chased and beaten passengers the previous Sunday , leaving 45 hospitalised .
By evening , the march had turned tense as demonstrators pushed close to villages surrounding the town , where some of the triads believed to be behind the attack are based .
Police shouted warnings through loudspeakers telling protesters they were involved in an illegal gathering and should leave immediately .

The protesters – many of whom were wearing black T-shirts and hard hats and were armed with shields made from boards of wood and surfboards , as well as hiking sticks and rods – retaliated by throwing umbrellas and water bottles .
Others hurled rocks and bottles at the police .
Demonstrators dismantled roadside barriers and built makeshift barricades between them and the police .
Police senior superintendent Yolanda Liu said in a late night press briefing that protesters had thrown bricks , bottles with corrosive liquid , and smoke bombs at police .
Hundreds of protesters remained , however , and continued to face off with the police late into the night , regrouping in the Yuen Long train station and along the main road .

In one episode that protesters and critics have begun comparing to the attack on passengers in Yuen Long last week , a special tactical unit rushed into the train station where protesters had gathered , some getting ready to go home .
Hong Kong ’ s hospital authority said 17 people had been hospitalised following the clashes , including two who were in serious condition .

Earlier , a group of protesters had smashed the windows of a Lexus near the train station after spotting rods similar to those used against passengers last Sunday , leaving fliers criticising the police on the bonnet .
The Hong Kong government said in a statement in the early hours of Sunday that protesters had also vandalised police cars and had blocked roads .
The police also issued a statement on Saturday reminding protesters that they were participating in an “ unauthorised assembly ” and could be punished with up to five years in prison .
The protests , which began over a controversial extradition bill , have evolved to take in other demands , including a police inquiry into the violence in Yuen Long last week .

Residents , activists and opposition lawmakers have accused the government and police of colluding with the triads in an attempt to suppress protests , a charge vehemently denied by Hong Kong ’ s chief executive , Carrie Lam .
Those attending the rally on Saturday said they were not there to make political demands , but to speak out against violence .

NEW YORK - The United States is committed to seeking justice for the victims of the 2008 Mumbai attack, no matter how "arduous" the task, a senior American diplomat of Indian origin said.

"We have certainly reaffirmed our support and commitment to India's efforts to seek justice on behalf of the victims of the 26 / 11 attack," Nisha Desai Biswal, Undersecretary of State for South and Central Asia, told PTI when asked about the delay in bringing the perpetrators of the 2008 terrorist attacks to justice.

Biswal, who arrived from Washington yesterday to speak at the Indian Consulate General's Media-India Lecture Series, said that not only a large number of Indian victims were killed in the attack, but also Americans.

Given that almost seven years have passed since the horrific terrorist attacks that claimed more than 160 lives and injured many others, Biswal said that bringing justice to the victims of terrorist attacks could be a laborious and lengthy process.
Biswal stressed that the US had offered rewards for information that led to the arrest and prosecution of people linked to the Mumbai attack.
Regarding the terrorist attack in the Gurdaspur district of Punjab on 27 July, Biswal said that the US had strongly condemned the attack and expressed its concern about it.
She said the US had expressed its co-operation with Indian authorities on specific aspects of the incident.

Responding to media reports that the night vision device used by three terrorists in the Gurdaspur attack had US markings, Biswal said the US was in talks with Indian authorities to try to determine and trace the origin of the equipment found.

"We will continue to work very closely with the Indian government on these issues," she said, adding that it is an ongoing process and the US is working with the Indian authorities to address issues arising from the incident.

On Thursday, Chen Daoxiang, the head of the Chinese army garrison in Hong Kong, said the military was "determined to protect [Hong Kong's] national sovereignty" and would help quell the "intolerable" unrest if asked.
Hong Kong police on Thursday charged 44 people linked to the protests with "unrest," a crime punishable by a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison.

Tens of thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators have marched through Hong Kong to mark the 20th anniversary of the country's return to Chinese control with a high-profile demonstration of dissent.
China's President Xi Jinping, who was on a three-day trip to the former British colony, flew out of Hong Kong on Saturday afternoon just hours before the start of annual protests in Victoria Park.

"We know that he has returned to Beijing, but we still want to show that they cannot ignore our voice," said Howard Cheng, 28, one of the leaders of the group organizing the rally, the Civil Rights Front (CHRF).

"We are here to fight for democracy and universal suffrage." According to the organizers, more than 60,000 people took part in the three-kilometer march, which has been held almost every year since Hong Kong was returned to China in 1997.
Saturday's rally, which will be followed by a huge pro-Beijing fireworks display to celebrate the anniversary, began around 3.30pm local time.

A column of demonstrators stormed from the park toward Hong Kong's financial center, carrying flags, banners, and yellow umbrellas - the symbol of the 2014 mass protests - that read, "Power to the People."

Many protesters wore dissenting messages on black-and-white T-shirts with slogans such as "Never Give Up," "Fight for Hong Kong," and, more poetically, "Being born in uncertain times carries certain responsibilities."
We are here to tell the world, "Nathan Law, a local pro-democracy lawmaker who was one of the leaders of the rally, told the Guardian.
Eddie Chu, a 39-year-old environmentalist and pro-democracy politician, said the rally was "the most important chance to show the power of the people."
That's what we need. "Jason Leung, a 16-year-old protester, marched with a poster that had a slightly different message.
"I think it's very selfish," said the teenager, who attended his first rally, saying he came because he wanted to see first-hand Hong Kong's vibrant democracy movement.
Hong Kong is not China. "Xi Jinping was hundreds of miles away at the start of Saturday's protests, but left a clear message to protesters before leaving.

In a speech before the protests began, he said Hong Kong must not be used as a launching pad to challenge Beijing's authority, and any questioning of Chinese sovereignty in the area "crosses a red line."
Both issues remain deeply unpopular with city dwellers, and previous attempts by the government to enact security laws and national education sparked mass protests.

Thousands of heavily armed troops have marched through cities in China's restive far west, where officials vowed a "thunderous" crackdown on terror after an apparent increase in deadly ethnic violence.

The parades follow two separate outbreaks of bloodletting that have claimed more than a dozen lives in Xinjiang, a sprawling border region plagued by repeated outbreaks of ethnic violence and terrorist attacks.
Last Tuesday, three machete-wielding attackers were reportedly gunned down by police after killing five civilians in Hotan's Pishan district.
On December 28, four attackers were reportedly shot dead after using homemade explosives to launch a deadly attack on a government compound in Karakax County.

China says Islamic extremists and separatists are behind the attacks, though human rights activists suspect much of the violence is driven by resentment against Communist Party rule among the predominantly Muslim Uighur population in the region.

OPINION India's Pakistan problem is also Pakistan's problem 3. December 2008 00: 00 IST Siddharth Varadarajan If India's response is not dictated by politics and emotion, the terrorist attacks in Mumbai could be a catalyst for ending the Pakistani military's fatal patronage of jihadist groups.

In the charged atmosphere created by the dangerous currents of domestic politics and the panic generated by the media, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh is under enormous pressure to respond firmly to initial indications that "elements in Pakistan" were responsible for last week's terrorist attacks in Mumbai.

Foreign Minister Pranab Mukherjee began sober and dignified last week when he told his Pakistani counterpart that the elements responsible for the carnage did not want a "leap forward" in India-Pakistan relations and were therefore acting against Islamabad's interests.

And on Monday, India issued a démarche to Pakistan, saying it expected "decisive action" against those responsible for the attacks, "whoever they may be." But, with television stations proclaiming "enough is enough" and calling for the start of a "real war" on terror, the government is increasingly on the defensive.
It is too early to say how these calls for an immediate and decisive response to what happened in Mumbai will affect relations with Pakistan.

One would think that the futility of offensive troop deployments and the suspension or downgrading of normal transport and diplomatic relations - methods that the BJP-led Vajpayee government tried unsuccessfully after the terrorist attack on parliament in December 2001 - would now be evident.

"But the stronger the political and media pressure, the more difficult it will be for us to exercise these options." Of course, the perpetrators of the terrorist attack on Pakistan would like India to be involved in an aggressive and preferably military response.

Thanks to the arbitrary arrest and subsequent interrogation of a terrorist in Mumbai, the police claim with considerable confidence that LeT planned and organized the attacks that killed more than 180 people.

Whether the terrorists who attacked Mumbai belong to a group that attacked Pakistani targets or had links to elements within Pakistan's military establishment, there is ample evidence that the Rawalpindi GHQ is unable to protect them.
The brutal murder of Daniel Pearl showed how easily a Kashmir-inspired terrorist like Omar Saeed Sheikh could make Al Qaeda's agenda his own.
And the targeted attacks on American and British citizens and Jews in the Mumbai attacks should serve as another reminder to Washington of the danger of giving groups like LeT every reprieve.

NEW DELHI - The NIA indictment leaves the Criminal Police Department red-faced 26. December 2011 14: 32 NEW DELHI: The investigation by Mumbai's elite crime unit into the role of Fahim Ansari and Sabbauddin Ahmed in the plot behind the November 26 attacks makes no mention of the NIA's comprehensive indictment into the role of Pakistani-American LeT terrorist David Headley in the Mumbai attack.

The 60-page indictment, filed by the National Investigation Agency (NIA) in a special court in New Delhi on Saturday, describes 50-year-old Headley's reconnaissance activities on the targets attacked by Lashker-e-Taiba (LeT) terrorists on 26 November 2008, in which 166 people died.

The Mumbai Crime Branch had accused Ansari and Sabbauddin of providing details of the targets attacked by LeT during a 60-hour gun battle, and faced embarrassment twice when the court and Bombay Supreme Court acquitted them because there was no evidence against them.

The former police chief of Mumbai, Hasan Gafoor, and the head of the Criminal Police Force at the time, Rakesh Maria, who is currently head of the counter-terrorism unit, had repeatedly claimed that Ansari and Ahmed had carried out reconnaissance of various targets attacked by Lashkar terrorists on 26 November 2008.

In its appeal, the Criminal Division had again alleged that Ansari and Ahmed had played a role in providing the Pakistan-based terrorist group with details of the targets attacked by terrorists on 26 November.
The investigative agency has investigated Headley and eight others, including Lashker founder Hafiz Saeed, 26 / 11 mastermind Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi and two serving Pakistani army officers.

Headley's statement to the US authorities and the NIA, which appears as an appendix to the indictment, speaks of his role in conducting the investigation of the sites attacked by the terrorists on 26 / 11.

The bench of Bombay Supreme Court judges, consisting of Justices Ranjana Desai and R. V. More, rejected the state government's appeal earlier this year, but said, "We believe that the experienced Judge Sessions's view regarding the duo's involvement in this case cannot be called unreasonable, patently false, patently flawed, and demonstratively untenable, justifying our interference." The Supreme Court agreed with Judge Sessions that the card, which was recovered from the slain terrorist's pocket, should have some wrinkles and blood stains because the LeT terrorist was seriously injured in the shooting.
The NIA has released details of how each target attacked by LeT terrorists was scouted by Headley, who is currently in a Chicago jail.

Nearly three months after an AIADMK official was chased and hacked to death in front of the public near the bustling Chengalpattu government hospital, the victim's wife and relatives went on a hunger strike and called on the police to arrest the masterminds of the murder.

Some of the biggest Maoist guerrilla attacks of the past: 6 April 2010: 76 security forces, 75 of whom belonged to the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF), were slaughtered by Maoists in the forested hamlet of Chintalnar in the Dantewada district.
4 April: Maoists detonate powerful landmines and blow up a police bus in the district of Koraput, Orissa, killing about 10 members of the Special Operations Group and injuring 16.
23 March: Maoists blow up a railway track in the Gaya district of Bihar, causing the derailment of the Rajdhani Express between Bhubaneswar and New Delhi.
On the same day, an empty freight train derailing on the Howrah-Mumbai line derails in a landmine attack in Orissa.
15 February 2010: Around 100 Maoists storm a police camp in Silda, West Bengal, killing 24 policemen and looting weapons.
8 October: 17 policemen were killed in an ambush by Maoists at Laheri police station in the Gadchiroli district of Maharashtra.
27 July 2009: Six CRPF men are killed in a landmine explosion in the Dantewada district of Chhattisgarh.
12 July: Thirty members of the security forces are killed in three attacks in the Rajnandgaon district of Chhattisgarh.
23 June: A group of armed Maoists on motorcycles opens fire on the grounds of the Lakhisarai District Court in Bihar in order to free four of their men.
10 June: During a routine patrol in the jungle of Saranda in Jharkhand, nine security forces, including CRPF soldiers, are ambushed by Maoists.
22 May 2009: Maoists kill 16 policemen in the jungle of Gadchiroli district in Maharashtra.
13 April: Ten policemen are killed in the Koraput district of eastern Orissa when Maoists attack a government bauxite mine.

July 25: Terror strikes the IT capital of Bangalore as at least nine consecutive low-intensity bombings strike the city, leaving two dead and several injured.

29 June: 35 members of the security forces of the Greyhounds of Andhra Pradesh were killed in a Naxal attack on a 68-member Andhra Pradesh-Orissa police party in the Chitrakonda reservoir in the district of Malkangiri near the border with Andhra Pradesh.

Anti-government protesters in Hong Kong occupied key streets early Monday amid rising tensions ahead of an expected large pro-democracy rally on the anniversary of the city's handover to China.
The semi-autonomous city was rocked by historic demonstrations last month when demonstrators demanded the repeal of a bill that would allow extradition to mainland China.

While an official ceremony was held at Hong Kong's Congress and Exhibition Centre to mark the 22nd anniversary of Britain's surrender of sovereignty to China, tensions rose again in the financial capital after hundreds of mostly young, masked protesters, mostly dressed in black and wearing caps and goggles, occupied three key thoroughfares, some of them erecting metal and plastic barriers to block the way.
Hundreds of protesters shouted "Withdraw the law of evil" at one point in the pouring rain.
On Lung Wo Road, some protesters dug up bricks and erected barricades of metal railings by the side of the road.
The ongoing rallies are the latest expression of growing fears that China, with the help of the financial center's pro-Beijing leadership, is suppressing the city's freedoms and culture.
Hong Kong has seen large-scale protests in recent years, including a two-month occupation in 2014 - without Beijing making any concessions.

This year's rally comes against the backdrop of unprecedented anti-government protests over the past three weeks, which have drawn millions of people and anger over police use of tear gas and rubber bullets to clear crowds.

Millions of people have taken to the streets to protest against the planned law allowing individuals to be extradited for trial in mainland China, where the opaque judicial system is controlled by the Communist Party.

The June protests were largely peaceful, but the scene turned violent on June 12, when police used rubber bullets, tear gas, pepper spray, and batons to disperse the crowd and some demonstrators threw objects at police.

Demonstrators have twice surrounded police headquarters in recent weeks in loud and emotionally charged protests, with young people spraying obscenities on the wall of the building and barricading the entrances.

While the spark of the current wave of protests has jumped to Chief Executive Carrie Lam's attempt to pass the Beijing-backed extradition law, the demonstrations have morphed into a broader movement against Lam's government and Beijing.

Lam - who has kept a low profile since rising from the public eye and has record low approval ratings - struck a conciliatory tone at Monday's handover ceremony, saying a series of protests that have rocked her city have taught her that she needs to listen better to the youth and people in general.

Eddy Chu Hoi-dick, a pro-democracy lawmaker, said that while he is concerned about the outbreak of violence, he believes the young demonstrators in the leaderless protests "have a consensus about when to back down" and avoid arrest.
On Sunday, thousands of pro-government demonstrators gathered outside the government headquarters to support the city's police.
Many waved Chinese flags and hurled insults at anti-government protesters camped nearby, highlighting the deep ideological rifts that now divide the financial center.

GADCHIROLI - Three teenagers from Pune who were kidnapped by Naxals in Chhattisgarh last month and released after five days said today that they had not been mistreated in any way by their captors.

They said the Naxals did not hurt or mistreat them during their captivity.

As part of their campaign "Bharat Jodo" (Link India), the youth had started a bicycle rally from Pune on 20 December to spread the message of peace in Maharashtra, Chhattisgarh and Odisha, the states most affected by Naxalism.

"As part of our mission, we examined the lives of people in remote and Naxal-affected tribal areas and did not expect to be kidnapped by the Naxals, even though we knew about their presence," they said.

A few hours after the Chinese government made it clear that the people of Hong Kong will not have a free choice if they vote for the next chief executive of the territory, the Hong Kong police made the first arrests of demonstrators protesting against this decision.
This led to violent protests across the city the next day, with one group of students even storming onto the university campus demanding the dismissal of the teacher who had asked the question.

A peaceful march in the city of Yuen Long condemning an attack by suspected gang members on commuters turned violent when Hong Kong riot police fired tear gas and rubber bullets at the crowd and used batons to beat protesters.
According to organizers, nearly 300,000 demonstrators and residents defied a police ban to storm the city in Hong Kong's western New Territories on Saturday afternoon.
They marched to the subway station, where masked men in white T-shirts had chased and beaten passengers the previous Sunday, and 45 of them were hospitalized.
By evening, the march had become tense as demonstrators pushed into the vicinity of villages around the city, where some of the triads suspected of being behind the attack are stationed.
Police shouted warnings over loudspeakers and told demonstrators that they were taking part in an illegal rally and should leave immediately.
The demonstrators - many wearing black T-shirts and hats and armed with wooden boards and surfboards, as well as walking sticks and poles - fought back by throwing umbrellas and water bottles.
Others threw rocks and bottles at police.
Demonstrators dismantled roadblocks and set up makeshift barricades between them and police.
Police Chief Commissioner Yolanda Liu said in a late evening news conference that protesters threw bricks, bottles of corrosive liquid and smoke bombs at police.
Hundreds of demonstrators remained, however, and continued to clash with police late into the night, who formed at Yuen Long railway station and along the main road.

In an episode that protesters and critics compare to last week's attack on passengers in Yuen Long, a special tactical unit stormed the station where protesters had gathered, some getting ready to go home.
Hong Kong's hospital authority said 17 people were hospitalized after the clashes, including two in serious condition.

Earlier, a group of protesters smashed the windows of a Lexus near the station after discovering bars similar to those used against passengers last Sunday and left leaflets criticising police on the bonnet.
The Hong Kong government said in a statement in the early hours of Sunday that protesters had also demolished police cars and blocked roads.
Police also reminded protesters in a statement Saturday that they had participated in an "unauthorized gathering" and could face up to five years in prison.
The protests, which began over a controversial extradition law, have evolved to include other demands, including a police investigation into the violence in Yuen Long last week.

Residents, activists and opposition lawmakers have accused the government and police of colluding with the triads to suppress protests - a charge that Hong Kong's chief executive Carrie Lam vehemently denies.
Participants in Saturday's rally said they had not come to make political demands, but to speak out against violence.
Demonstrators surrounded the police headquarters and chanted, "Black police" - a reference to the triads known in China as "black societies."

"If every Hong Kong person decides to stay home, we will surely die... In this way, Hong Kongers show their trust in each other - by turning up and standing up for each other." Anger over last week's attack by Yuen Long has added fuel to the protest movement in Hong Kong, with more rallies planned for Sunday.
On Friday, thousands of protesters staged an 11-hour sit-in at Hong Kong airport.
Authorities also rejected a request to hold one on Sunday in Sheung Wan, where police fired tear gas and rubber bullets at protesters who defaced the Chinese embassy in Hong Kong last week.
Max Chung, who helped organize Saturday's rally, said he believed residents had shown their resolve: "Hong Kongers have stiffened their back to say no to authoritarianism."

OPINION India's Pakistan problem is also Pakistan's problem 03 December 2008 00: 00 IST Siddharth Varadarajan If politics and emotions do not dictate India's response, the terrorist attacks in Mumbai could be the catalyst for ending Pakistan's fatal patronage of jihadist militant groups.

In a tense atmosphere engendered by dangerous domestic politics and media panic, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh is under enormous pressure to respond decisively to initial evidence that "elements in Pakistan" were responsible for last week's terrorist atrocity in Mumbai.

Foreign Minister Pranab Mukherjee made a sober and dignified start last week when he told his Pakistani counterpart that the elements responsible for the carnage did not want a "leap forward" in India-Pakistan relations and were also acting against Islamabad's interests.
And on Monday, India issued a demarche to Pakistan, saying it expected "strong action" against those responsible for the attacks, "whoever they may be."
It is too early to tell how these demands for an immediate and decisive response to what happened in Mumbai will affect relations with Pakistan.

The seeming futility of military offensives and the suspension or downgrading of normal transport and diplomatic relations - methods that the Vajpak government, led by the BJP, tried unsuccessfully after the terrorist attack on Parliament in December 2001 - would already be apparent.
The perpetrators of the terrorist attack on Pakistan certainly do not want India to fall into the trap of an aggressive, preferable, military response.

Thanks to the pre-emptive arrest of the terrorist in Mumbai and his subsequent interrogation, the police claim with considerable confidence that LeT planned and carried out the attacks that killed more than 180 people.

Regardless of whether the terrorists who attacked Mumbai belonged to the group that attacked Pakistani targets, or whether they had operatives linked to elements in the Pakistani military establishment, there is enough evidence to suggest that the GHQ in Rawalpindi cannot insulate them from each other.
The brutal murder of Daniel Pearl showed how easily a "Kashmiri-inspired" terrorist like Omar Said Sheikh could make Al Qaeda's agenda his own.
And the deliberate attacks on American and British citizens and Jews in Mumbai should serve as yet another reminder to Washington of the dangers of giving groups like LeT breathing space.

The 60-page indictment, filed Saturday by the National Bureau of Investigation (NIA) in a special court in New Delhi, details the 50-year-old Headley's efforts to destroy targets attacked by Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT) terrorists on November 26, 2008, killing 166 people.

Mumbai accused Fahari and Sabbauddin of having provided details of the targets attacked by LeT during the 60-hour firefight, and they had to stand trial twice when the Bombay Court of First Instance and High Court acquitted both, saying there was no evidence against them.

Former Mumbai Police Commissioner Hassan Ghafoor and the then head of the criminal division, Rakesh Maria, who now heads the anti-terrorism squad, have repeatedly alleged that Fazari and Ahmed carried out a series of attacks on various targets attacked by Lashkar terrorists on November 26, 2008.

In their motion for reconsideration, the Crime Division reiterated that Fahari and Ahmed played a role in providing detailed information to the Pakistan-based terrorist group about the targets attacked on November 26.

The investigation took on the role of Headley and eight others, including the founder of Lashkar-e-Said, the mastermind of the 26 / 11 terrorist attack, Zaki-ur-Hamad, and two serving Pakistani army officers.

Headley, who was recruited by Lashkar-e-Taiba, told the US authorities and the NRA before a magistrate judge, one of the burning points of the indictment, about his role in surveying the sites attacked by the terrorists of 26 / 11.

The High Court agreed with Judge Sessions that the map taken from the murdered terrorist's pocket should have traces of blood, as Terrorist LeT was seriously wounded in the crossfire.
The National Security Agency released details of how Headley, who is currently in a Chicago prison, tracked every target attacked by LeT terrorists.

A Timeline of Major Maoist Attacks 17 May 2010 19: 32 NEW DELHI: The deadly attack by Maoist guerrillas on a civilian bus in the Chhattisgarh district of Dantewada on Monday night came just over a month after a brazen attack by left-wing insurgents on April 6 on security forces in the same area that killed 76 people.

Some of the largest Maoist guerrilla attacks in the past: on 6 April 2010, in the abandoned village of Chintalnar in Dantewada district, the Maoists killed 76 members of the security forces, 75 of whom were assigned to the Central Reserve Police Force (CPF).
4 April 2010: Maoists detonated a powerful landmine and blew up a police bus in Koraput district, Orion, killing about 10 special forces personnel and wounding 16.
March 23, 2010: Maoists blow up railway tracks in Bayar Gaya district, derailing the Bhubaneswar-New Delhi-Rajdhani express train.
On the same day, a mine explosion in Eastern Ghouta derailed an empty train and hit the tracks on the Khoura-Mumbai train line.
15 February 2010: Around 100 Maoists storm a police camp in Silda, West Bengal, killing 24 policemen and looting weapons.
8 September 2009: Seventeen policemen killed in a Maoist attack on a police station in Lahri, Gadchiroli district of Maharashtra.
July 27, 2009: Six men are killed by a landmine explosion in the Dantewada district of Chhattisgarh.
12 July 2009: Three separate attacks in Rajnandgaon district of Chhattisgarh state claimed the lives of 30 members of the security forces.
23 June 2009: A group of armed Maoists on motorcycles attacked the district court building in Hisaray to free four of them.
10 June 2009: Nine members of the security forces, including CRPF soldiers, were captured by the Maoists during a routine patrol in Saranda, Jharkhand State.
22 May 2009: Maoists kill 16 policemen in the Gadchiroli district of Maharashtra.
April 13, 2009: About 10 policemen are killed in the eastern district of Koraput when Maoists attack a state-owned bauxite mine.

HIDERABAD: Amid fears large-scale violence, especially in the Rayalasima region, the second round of voting took place peacefully in the state, with the exception of the death of a polling station worker in Faam district, while activists from rival political parties were in several locations.

Anti-government demonstrators in Hong Kong seized key roads early Monday amid rising tensions ahead of what is expected to be a huge pro-democracy rally on the anniversary of the city's handover to China.
Last month, the dilapidated city was rocked by historic events when protesters demanded the withdrawal of a bill allowing extradition to mainland China.

While an official ceremony was held at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre to mark the 22nd anniversary of Kennedy's return from Britain to China, tensions in the financial center spiked again after hundreds of protesters, mostly masked young men, mostly in black, wearing camouflage suits and glasses, seized three key thoroughfares, some of which were cordoned off with metal and plastic barriers to block the way.
At one point, in the pouring rain, protesters shouted "betray the law of evil."

The ongoing rallies are further evidence of growing fears that China is striking a blow to the city's freedom and culture with the help of the financial center's pro-Beijing leaders.
In recent years, there have been large-scale protests in Hong Kong, including a two-month occupation in 2014 - but no concessions from Beijing have been forthcoming.
This year's rally comes amid unprecedented anti-government protests over the past three weeks that have attracted millions and anger at police using tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse crowds.

Millions of people have taken to the streets to protest a proposed law that would allow people to be extradited for trial to mainland China, where an opaque judicial system is controlled by the Communist Party.

Protests throughout June were largely peaceful, but the scene turned violent on June 12, when police used rubber bullets, tear gas, pepper spray and batons to disperse the crowd, with some protesters throwing objects back at police.

Demonstrators have also twice in recent weeks surrounded the police headquarters in noisy and emotionally charged protests, in which young people sprayed profanities on its facade and barricaded its doors.

While the spark for the current wave of protests was Chief Executive Carrie Lam's attempt to pass a Beijing-backed extradition law, the protests have morphed into a broader movement against the Lam and Beijing administrations.

Lam, who has been in hiding from the public since leaving office and has record low approval ratings, said at Monday's handover ceremony that the series of protests that have rocked her city has taught her that she needs to listen better to young people and people in general.

Eddie Chu Hoy-, a pro-democracy legislator, said that while he is concerned about the outbreaks of violence, he believes that young protesters in protests without leaders have "a consensus about when they should step back" and avoid arrest.
On Sunday, thousands of pro-government demonstrators gathered outside the government building to support the city's police.
Many waved Chinese flags and hurled insults at anti-government demonstrators stationed nearby, underscoring the deep ideological fissures that now divide the financial center.

Hours after the Chinese government signaled that Hong Kong's people would not have a free choice when they voted to elect the territory's new chief executive, Hong Kong police carried out the first arrests of demonstrators protesting the decision.
This led to violent protests across the city the next day, when a group of students even stormed the campus and demanded the dismissal of the teacher who had asked the question.

A peaceful march in the city of Yuen Long to denounce an attack by alleged gang members on commuter trains turned violent when Hong Kong riot police fired tear gas and rubber bullets at the crowd, as well as batons to beat protesters.
Nearly 300,000 protesters and Hong Kong residents on Saturday afternoon desecrated a police ban on the city in Hong Kong's western New Territories, organizers said.
They marched to a public transport stop where, last Sunday, masked men in white T-shirts beat up passengers, resulting in 45 people being hospitalized.
By the evening, the march had become tense as demonstrators approached villages surrounding the city, where some of the triads believed to be behind the attack are based.
Police shouted warnings over loudspeakers, telling protesters that they were participating in an illegal gathering and should leave immediately.
The protesters, many of whom were wearing black t-shirts and hard hoods, were armed with wooden shields and surfboards, as well as sticks and rods, and responded by throwing stones and water bottles.
Others threw stones and bottles at the police.
Policemen dismantled roadblocks and erected barricades between them and the police.
Senior Police Superintendent Yolanda Liu said at an evening press briefing that protesters threw stones, corrosive liquid bottles and smoke bombs at police.
However, some protesters remained and continued to clash with police late into the night, scuffling at Yuen Long railway station and along the main road.

In one episode, which protesters and critics have begun to compare to the attack on passengers in Yuen Long last week, a special tactical unit stormed a train station where protesters had gathered, some of whom were preparing to head home.
Hong Kong hospital officials said 17 people were hospitalized after the clashes, two of whom are in serious condition.

Earlier, a group of protesters smashed the windows of a Lexus car outside a train station after noticing bars similar to those used against passengers last Sunday, leaving leaflets on the bonnet criticizing the police.
Hong Kong's government said in a statement early Sunday that protesters also smashed police vehicles and blocked roads.
Police also issued a statement Saturday reminding protesters that they were participating in an "unauthorized gathering" and could face up to five years in prison.
Protests over the controversial extradition bill have escalated into other demands, including a police investigation into last week's violence in Yuen Long.

Local residents, activists, and opposition lawmakers have accused the government and police of colluding with the triads to try to quell the protests, charges Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam has vehemently denied.
Participants in Saturday's rally said they had come here not to make political demands, but to speak out against the violence.
Protesters surrounded the police headquarters, chanting "Black police" - a reference to triads known in Chinese as "black owls."
Anger over Yuen Loong's attack last week has added fuel to the fire of Hong Kong's protest movement, with more rallies planned for Sunday.
On Friday, thousands of protesters staged an 11-hour sit-in at Hong Kong's airport.

Authorities also rejected a request to hold a demonstration Sunday in Shenwan, not far from where police fired tear gas and rubber bullets at demonstrators who desecrated China's mission in Hong Kong last week.
Max Chung, who helped organize Saturday's rally, said he believed residents had shown their resolve: "People have resigned themselves to saying no to authoritarianism."
